title: AI for Boilerplate and Pattern Implementation - Knowledge Check

questions.question: What is AI particularly effective at in DDD/CQRS development?

options.text: Generating boilerplate code for entities, value objects, and repositories

questions.explanation: AI excels at generating repetitive pattern implementations like entities, value objects, repositories, commands, and queries. It struggles with domain understanding, business decisions, and aggregate boundary definition.

questions.question: When using AI to generate DDD code, you should always review the generated business rules for domain accuracy.
questions.explanation: AI cannot understand your specific business domain. You must always review AI-generated code for business rule accuracy, validate invariants, ensure domain language is correct, and confirm events include necessary data.

questions.question: What is a common pitfall of AI-generated DDD code?

options.text: Over-generic implementations that miss domain-specific business rules

questions.explanation: AI often generates overly generic code that lacks domain-specific validation, business rules, and state transition logic. You must refine the code to include specific business constraints from your domain.

questions.question: AI can effectively replace domain experts when modeling business requirements.
questions.explanation: AI cannot replace domain experts. It cannot understand your specific business context, talk to stakeholders, or make strategic decisions about the domain. Humans must gather requirements and validate that AI-generated code aligns with business needs.

questions.question: What should be included in an effective prompt for AI to generate DDD entities?

options.text: Properties, business rules, domain events, and implementation requirements
A simple description like 'make an Order class'

questions.explanation: Effective prompts should include properties, business rules, domain events to raise, implementation requirements (validation, factory methods, invariant protection), and technology constraints (TypeScript, strict typing).
